thread.title: BC’s Walker finds special place
thread.title_full: BC’s Walker finds special place | Boston Herald

author: Rich Thompson
title: BC’s Walker finds special place
text:
Michael Walker played quarterback in high school, was recruited as a defensive back and is now returning kicks and playing wide receiver for Boston College.
The 6-foot, 195-pound true freshman will look to expand his role in the BC passing game while maintaining a solid kick return average when the Eagles (3-3, 0-3) battle the No. 5 Clemson Tigers (5-0, 2-0) in an Atlantic Coast Conference match tomorrow night at Memorial Stadium.
“I was basically recruited as an athlete and I was open to do anything I could to help the team out,” said Walker. “I did kick returns in high school and obviously as a true freshman I’m going to try anything to get on the field.”
Walker has been a stalwart on the Eagles’ beleaguered special teams since replacing injured tailback Myles Willis (shoulder) as the deep man on the kick return unit.
“I think he’s going to be an exciting player,” said BC coach Steve Addazio. “I think Walker has done a great job, he’s a very exciting young player. He makes some plays in practice that grab your attention and I think we’re coming along at the wide receiver position.”
Walker has amassed 155 yards on five returns for a 31-yard average, which is third in the ACC behind Louisville’s Traveon Samuel and Kermit Whitfield of Florida State. Willis is expected to resume his duties as a rotating tailback against Clemson but won’t be involved in the return game.
“The big question is whether we want to expose Willis back to those high velocity explosive hits right away,” said Addazio. “But I love Myles and Walker as a return duo.”
Walker returned kicks, punts and played in the secondary at Naples High School in Naples, Fla., in addition to running the Golden Eagles veer offense. The veer triple option scheme exposed Walker to the kind of violent hits he takes on the suicide squad.
Willis was a quarterback at Marist High School in Atlanta., but didn’t partake in specials teams until he came to The Heights.
“I worked on it a bit in training camp and when Myles got hurt I found my niche,” Walker said. “The coaches tell me just try and get vertical and as long as you get vertical you’ll find a hole if you run 100 miles an hour. But my success is totally about other players doing their jobs.”
Walker speaks with an easy south Florida accent but his athletic roots are in Connecticut. Walker’s uncle, Pete Walker, played baseball at UConn before spending eight seasons in the major leagues. He is currently the Toronto Blue Jays’ pitching coach.
Walker’s father, Mike, played football at UConn from 1979-82 while another uncle, Andrew Walker, played baseball for the Huskies.
“I grew up an athletic family with my dad and all of his brothers playing Division 1 sports,” he said.
Walker believes his time spent playing quarterback and defensive back in high school has provided a unique perspective for running pass routes in college.
